data_findings.finding: Pre-optimized santa-2025.csv scores 70.676102. Target is 68.919154. Gap is 1.75 points (2.54%). The santa-2025.csv is at a tight local optimum - short optimization runs find NO improvements. Need: 1) Much longer optimization runs (hours), 2) Lattice-based approach for large N, 3) Focus on small N values (1-10) which have highest score contribution.

tree_packer_v21.cpp uses: Swap moves, Multi-angle restarts, Higher temperature SA, squeeze (scale down until overlap), compaction (move trees toward center), localSearch. Key parameters: -n iterations, -r rounds. Uses long double precision. Processes all N values (1-200) in parallel with OpenMP.

bbox3 optimizer uses: Complex Number Vector Coordination, Fluid Dynamics, Hinge Pivot, Density Gradient Flow, Global Boundary Tension. Uses aggressive_repair for overlap resolution. Key parameters: -n iterations, -r rounds. Uses OpenMP for parallelization.

Score breakdown: N=1-10 contributes 4.33 (6.13%), N=1-50 contributes 19.04 (26.94%), N=51-100 contributes 17.64, N=101-200 contributes 33.99. N=1 is already optimal at 45 degrees (side=0.813). Small N values have lowest efficiency (1.5-2.6 trees/unit area).

web_research.query: What are the best techniques for 2D irregular polygon packing to minimize bounding box area?
web_research.finding:
Two‑dimensional irregular‑polygon nesting is usually tackled by a combination of **exact optimisation** and **high‑performance heuristics**, each of which is designed to shrink the axis‑aligned bounding rectangle (the “bounding box”) as much as possible.

*Exact approaches* model the placement of non‑convex pieces as a global non‑linear programme.  Jones (2013) introduced a fully general exact algorithm that replaces the non‑overlap constraints between polygons with constraints between a small set of **inscribed circles**; the resulting quadratic‑programming sub‑problems give tight lower bounds, while a local‑search phase supplies feasible upper bounds ([springer](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10898-013-0129-z)).  A related “phi‑function” technique solves small instances of convex polygons to optimality with the global NLP solver BARON, directly minimising the perimeter (and thus the area) of the enclosing rectangle ([semanticscholar](https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/bf98/
